answers.author: Shawn Gillen
answers.text:
There is no magic number for a minimum or maximum fund balance.  Each city must evaluate the stability of its revenue sources, cash flow needs and probability of an emergency/disaster.   Because the volatility of the intergovernmental revenue we receive from the state,  the relatively high probability of massive snow removal expenditures and the desire to maintain a relatively high bond rating, our policy sets a minimum reserve of 75% of annual revenues.  This allows us to cash flow up to seven months of the year until we get our first tax disbursement and intergovernmental revenue disbursement.  We have also developed a revenue stabilization policy to deal with mid-year delays and or reductions in the intergovernmental revenue.  We can borrow, from our fund balance, up to 10% of annual revenues over a two year period following a national recession.  We must then pay back the fund balance over the following eight years or until the minimum fund balance is restored.

answers.author: Stephen Erlandson
answers.text:
Stephen J. Gauthier, Director of the GFOA's Technical Services Center, wrote an article in the December 2009 issue of Government Finance Review addressing what the GFOA believes to be the best practice on Fund Balance and reserves.  In the article, Gauthier states the GFOA recommends that general-purpose governments maintain no less than two months worth of operating revenues or regular general fund operating expenditures.
